title: Commemorating the 50th Christian Education Week Anniversary of Cornerstone Baptist Church
fulltext:
LEGISLATIVE  RESOLUTION  commemorating the 50th Christian Education Week
Anniversary of Cornerstone Baptist Church  to  be  celebrated  September
27-October 1, 2010

WHEREAS,  Religious  institutions,  and  the  many spiritual, social and
educational benefits they confer, play a vital role in  the  development
of the moral fabric of a responsible citizenry; and
  WHEREAS,  It  is  the  tradition  of this State and this Nation to pay
tribute to those institutions and individuals who  have  contributed  to
the ethical and spiritual values of their communities; and
  WHEREAS,  This  Legislative  Body  takes pleasure in commemorating the
50th Christian Education Week Anniversary of Cornerstone Baptist  Church
to be celebrated September 27-October 1, 2010; and
  WHEREAS, In the fall of 1960, Cornerstone Baptist Church embarked on a
journey  of fellowship and Bible Study; since the inception of Christian
Education Week, the congregation as well as many other community church-
es have set aside an annual week of intensive study of God's word; and
  WHEREAS, Located on the corner of Dr. Sandy F. Ray Boulevard and Madi-
son Street in Brooklyn, New York, Cornerstone Baptist Church has magnif-
icent and impressive facilities and the  sanctuary  is  famous  for  its
warm, rich and elegant structural design; and
  WHEREAS, A place in which the motto "Welcome and Worship Are Warm" has
real  meaning, Cornerstone Baptist Church has grown from a few people in
1917 to in excess of 1500 members today; and
  WHEREAS, Cornerstone Baptist Church has some sixty-five Boards,  clubs
and  organizations  that  offer  every member a mini-home where they can
expand their talents and indulge their special interests; and
  WHEREAS, In addition, Cornerstone  Baptist  Church  has  a  large  and
active  Sunday  school  program,  including  a month long Vacation Bible
School during the summer, which is free to the public; it also  supports
five choirs for every age and musical ability; and
  WHEREAS, In 1917, a small group held their first meeting at 933 DeKalb
Avenue,  in Brooklyn, New York; this group continued to worship together
and on September 10, 1917, the Cornerstone Baptist Church was  organized
and dedicated to the Service of God; and
  WHEREAS, On May 3, 1920, a meeting was held to organize this body into
a  permanent church and the six Baptist Churches which formed the Recog-
nition Council officially recognized Cornerstone Baptist Church on  June
9, 1920, by holding a public service; and
  WHEREAS,  The founder and first Pastor, Reverend William H. Rodman was
called from labor to reward in February  1921;  later  that  same  year,
Reverend A. R. Artis became the Pastor of Cornerstone Baptist Church and
served until May 1922; and
  WHEREAS,  Later  in 1922, the Reverend J. J. Jenkins became Pastor; he
was followed by the Reverend J. R. Williams who served from  1925  until
his death on June 16, 1929; and
  WHEREAS,  The  Reverend  Thomas  Willis  Fentress  was  then called to
pastor; under his pastorate, the church moved to 688 DeKalb  Avenue  and
in  1932 Cornerstone Baptist Church moved to its first church edifice at
Gates Avenue and Irving Place; and
  WHEREAS, On April 1, 1944, the Reverend Dr. Sandy Frederick  Ray,  who
had  pastored three churches and was pastor of the Shiloh Baptist Church
in Columbus, Ohio, was called to Cornerstone Baptist Church; and
  WHEREAS, At this time, the Cornerstone Baptist Church congregation had
grown so large that the church edifice at Gates Avenue and Irving  Place
could  no  longer  accommodate  it;  a contract was signed for the Lewis

Avenue Congregational Church Parish on December 28, 1944, and the  march
from the old church to the new took place on June 10, 1945; and
  WHEREAS,  During the Reverend Dr. Sandy Frederick Ray's 35 year minis-
try at Cornerstone Baptist Church,  new  buildings  were  purchased  and
erected to house the church office and the pastor's study; and
  WHEREAS,  After  the  Reverend  Dr. Sandy Frederick Ray passed away on
April 11, 1979, his assistant, the Reverend Henry G. Scott  served  with
distinction as Minister-In-Charge of Cornerstone Baptist Church; and
  WHEREAS,  On  November 14, 1981, the Cornerstone Baptist Church Family
held an election and unanimously elected the Reverend Dr.  Harry  Starks
Wright,  a  Pastor,  Dean  and  College  President,  to the Pastorate of
Cornerstone Baptist Church; and
  WHEREAS, The seventh pastor of Cornerstone Baptist Church, the  Rever-
end Dr. Harry Starks Wright, began his ministry in March 1982; following
a  Pre-Installation Luncheon at the Waldorf Astoria on July 24, 1982, he
was installed as Pastor of Cornerstone Baptist Church  by  the  Reverend
Dr.  Gardner C. Taylor, Senior Pastor, Concord Baptist Church of Christ,
on Sunday, July 25, 1982; and
  WHEREAS, On August 3, 2003, Pastor Harry S.  Wright  retired  and  his
successor,  the  Reverend  Lawrence  Aker, who had served as Minister of
Discipleship and Evangelism, took the reins  as  Pastor  of  Cornerstone
Baptist Church; and
  WHEREAS,  Under  the  faithful  leadership  of Pastor Harry S. Wright,
Cornerstone Baptist Church stands on the threshold of tomorrow, prepared
to meet the challenges of the coming decades while retaining that  spir-
itual resolve which characterizes its past; and
  WHEREAS,  It  is  the  custom of this Legislative Body to take note of
enduring religious institutions and to bring such  institutions  to  the
attention of the people of this Empire State; now, therefore, be it
  RESOLVED,  That  this  Legislative  Body pause in its deliberations to
commemorate the 50th Christian Education Week Anniversary of Cornerstone
Baptist Church to be celebrated  September  27-October  1,  2010,  fully
confident  that  this  commemoration reflects the belief in those values
which enhance the dignity and purpose of life; and be it further
  RESOLVED, That a copy of this Resolution, suitably engrossed, be tran-
smitted to Cornerstone Baptist Church.
